values: . . . is there any point to anything any more?

At my old (and my brother's soon-to-be-old) school, they send a text message to a nomimated mobile phone number (preferably one belonging to the parent/guardian) asking why your child is absent. They also send messages regarding important events, such as the fact that your child's report is available for collection. When the system was first implemented, I was the only one in my family who had a mobile phone, so naturally I put my own number down. This came in handy when I got a text message on my mobile asking why I hadn't shown up to school when I was actually AT school. Cue running to the school office.

Anyway, so because all the messages are sent to my phone, it's up to me to send a reply back. Usually, this is what I send:

My son Michael x of roll class a.b was absent on 25/5/11 as I gave him permission to stay at home today due to the Athletics Carnival. Yours Sincerely, (my mum's name).

Here's some messages I wish I could have sent:

My brother Michael x of roll class a.b. was absent on 25/5/11 as he couldn't be bothered to go to the Athletics Carnival, EVEN THOUGH IT'S HIS LAST ONE - EVER. Oh, and he isn't going to his formal either. WTF? Yours Sincerely, Wendy x.

Or:

My brother Michael x of roll class a.b was absent on (date) as he has gastroenteritis. Yours Sincerely, Wendy x.

Oh, wait. I DID send that one once, complete with the proper spelling of gastro! Only under my mum's name and he really DID have gastro. Hope the office ladies who were reading the messages enjoyed that excuse!

Hey, nose.

Remember last year at the MCA Zine Fair how you kept leaking to the point where I had to go to Priceline to buy more tissues? I probably infected a dozen people there, too. You better not do that this year, especially since I have work right after.

I'M WARNING YOU, NOSE. NO SNOT, OK?

Yours Sincerely,

Wendy.

The voice is used to tell someone that you hate/love them. To yell at your family members. To ask your customers what they would like and to tell the sales assistant why you need to return what you just purchased. To argue a brilliant point and to gossip on the sly. To sing along to your favourite songs and to let out your frustration.

But if your voice can't do all that, then what's the point of having one at all?

Oh, Röyksopp. I think that anything you create is the bee's knees. The day you announce that you come to Australia will make me very happy indeed (and I will assume I have died then, because it feels like there's no way that you'll come to Australia while I'm still alive). Every time I'm required to fill out the favourite music/musicians/noises section in my profile, you are always listed first. But what's with the artwork for Senior?

It's the opposite of great. Is this the reason why no designer has yet to be credited with the design? The photo of the two of you as elderly people is cool, but what on earth is with the top and the bottom? Is the top supposed to be a chandelier? Crystals? It's the bottom that kills it the most, however. To put it bluntly - THAT FONT IS HORRIBLE. Now, I'm not a graphic designer (I leave that to my friends), but I do appreciate good album artwork - and good album artwork this is not. Leave the artist and album name off it (as is the case with at least half a dozen albums I own on CD), and it'll be fine. If you need to have the details on it, that's what stickers are for. To borrow from Robyn's Don't Fucking Tell Me What To Do (whose singing I loved on The Girl and The Robot from Junior and really, should be made into a SingStar song), that font is killing me. If you want to know how to do dark, minimalistic album covers, take a look at Pet Shop Boys' Fundamental, as a Facebook fan of yours suggested.

That being said, I cannot WAIT for Senior. An instrumental album by my favourite duo? HELL YES!

Love, Wendy.

Personally, I don't think any album artwork of Röyksopp's could beat the amazement that I felt when I examined the CD of their second album (and my favourite album when I'm awake) The Understanding:

(For those who might not be able to spot it, the ö in Röyksopp is the centre of the CD. I love it when the designer takes the object into account and works their way around it!)
Taken while in IKEA Homebush Bay, July 14 2010.

Last Friday, I got dressed in order to go to the RTA with my brother to fix up his licence, which was claiming that he was two days younger than he actually was; why he didn't do this earlier probably had something to do with our parents. Went downstairs, only to find a group of my brother's friends at the door, inviting him to go bike-riding. He ended up going bike-riding, leaving me all dressed up and nowhere to go . . . Except to Parramatta. I had been meaning to go to see if there was a chance I could knock something off my uni booklist with the Borders 30% off one full-priced book coupon while it was still valid. So off I went by myself to Parramatta, and unexpectedly came home with the following (with italics linked to the product in question):
  • A copy of The Cat Returns on DVD from JB Hi-Fi. Last time I bought a Studio Ghibli DVD for $20 was My Neighbor Totoro in December 2007. I've been stalking JB Hi-Fi ever since, waiting for another Studio Ghibli $20 sale. Even so, I was THIS close to missing out on this sale, which ended on the 19th, since I hadn't stalked JB Hi-Fi in a while. I actually jumped up and down when I saw that the DVDs were on sale, which I'm sure looked very dignified. *laughs* I had put myself on a DVD ban since I was buying all these movies, but not watching them until much later. But for a Studio Ghibli sale? Like hell I was going to miss out on that!
  • Three Popular Penguins books. Original intention was to buy Alice's Adventures In Wonderland (from the new set of 75 Popular Penguins for uni) with the 30% off coupon for Borders. The store computer said they had two copies, but neither I nor the sales assistant could find a copy. Same with a Nietzsche book (difference being that I looked for it myself without any help, and there was only one copy). The sales assistant said that they only got six titles from the new collection in, which I thought was pretty hopeless. Later wandered into Dymocks to see their Popular Penguins range - way more impressive than that of Borders! They seemed to have every single one of the 174 titles in stock, including Alice, Playing Beatie Bow and Dangerous Liaisons - all from the new collection of 75 titles and the latter two being on my books wishlist. With Dymocks offering a Popular Penguins tote bag with the purchase of three titles, I gave in, bought them - I REALLY wanted that tote bag when I saw it on the front cover of the latest Booklover magazine - and subsequently broke my book ban (which was imposed for the same reason as the DVD ban). But it was totally worth it for the bag. *dances*

  • A packet of tissues. I was walking back to my car when I saw a giant liquid dispenser:

    COOL! Not so cool when it turned out to be advertising Lifebuoy, which I swear has suddenly exploded onto the market; I'd never heard of the brand until a few months ago. I wasn't going to say no to a free packet of tissues, though. (I was expecting a hand wash or a hand sanitiser when the lady said 'free samples'.)

One thing's guaranteed - I sure won't be buying any more books or DVDs for at least a month . . .

Supposed to be cleaning my room at the moment - I can see what my desk looks like again - but I need a break; I've been cleaning my room since 7 a.m. and nowhere near finishing . . .
  • The lady who stole my parking spot at Westfield Liverpool at the post-Christmas sale in 2006, then told my brother (whom I sent out to negotiate as I couldn't abandon my car in the middle of the carpark) to respect his elders. How can you respect someone who just drives in without checking to see whether anyone's waiting for that spot? Age is not a consideration.
  • The idiotic postman from last year who bent my picture book in an attempt to wedge it into my mailbox, despite the fact that it was packaged in cardboard. THERE WAS A REASON IT WAS IN CARDBOARD - TO PROTECT IT FROM DAMAGE! DUH!
  • The fact that Marion and Jonathan got eliminated from MasterChef. Marion was bad enough, but to see Jonathan - who, after Marion left, was the best cook left in the competition - go in the next elimination, made me depressed, considering he was my favourite. Who knows who can win now . . . but you can guarantee I'll be in a fit of rage if it turns out to be Jimmy.

A year ago, the only cookbook I had on my bookcase was The Commonsense Cookery Book, which was purchased partly because it had recipes for people who can't cook like myself, and partly because it looked cool. All but three were purchased - Indulgence Petit Fours and Indulgence Slices was given to me for my 21st birthday by my cousin Jenny and frankie Magazine Afternoon Tea was given to me (also for my 21st) by Stephanie. Thanks Jenny and Stephanie!

Anyway, I wanted to talk about my latest acquisitions, Indulgence Coffee and Indulgence Chocolate - perfect timing for Winter! Not that I'll be making anything . . .

How is it that an Australian produced book is cheaper overseas?! I noticed that both books were available for pre-order for only $8.11 each, so I pre-ordered them before the price went up . They go for $29.95 each in the bookshop! $60 worth of cookbooks for $16! Delivered right to the door too, unlike the guy who managed to shove my cookbooks in the mailbox last year, which meant a couple of minutes trying to extract it from the slot, since it was too large to fit through the mailbox's door. Yay for the Book Depository! If only they weren't so sneaky with different pricing for different countries . . .

By the way, if you haven't read Azumanga Daioh, go and read it. It retails for $40 here. It would have cost me $60 for the above volumes if my friend Julie didn't buy me volume 3 for my birthday in 2006. $26 is cheap!

P. S. There's a new frankie cookbook. I want it! (Edit on 25/5/10 at 17:59) I have it! Thanks for agreeing to buy it for my birthday, Fiona! *hugs*
Sometimes, I wish could sleep forever and not wake up.

• Country Road tote bags make good cabin bags, contrary to what others (read: my parents) may believe. When we were waiting at Sydney Airport and Changi Airport, we spotted quite a number of Country Road bags. If a traveller has a Country Road bag, it's safe to assume that they're Australian.
  • Sydney Duty Free is still awesome, even if they don't do those yearly catalogues from the early 1990s any more.
  • They got rid of A&W at Penang Airport and replaced it with a McDonald's. Best decision ever - root beer sucks, having tried it in 1998.
  • Changi Airport won't let you leave the country with a pair of scissors in your pencil case. Sydney Airport will. Last time I EVER bring scissors in my cabin bag.
  • Changi Airport shits all over Sydney Airport. Sydney needs more free Internet hubs. Changi has tons! And I know I don't frequent airports often, but seriously, does Sydney have such awesome displays like Changi?

• Strawberries and ice cream
  • Scones
  • Popcorn (there's a free sample coupon in my Easter Show guide)
  • One of those hot hot hot sauces that burns your mouth (that was fun!)
  • Lunch . . . there's yum cha, Thai, pizza, hot chips . . .
I hope it doesn't rain today!

Out of all the weeks to not deliver the newspaper, this week is NOT the appropriate week to skip. This Sunday is the Sunday when the Sydney Royal Easter Show Guide is out in the Sunday Telegraph and I get very cranky if I don't have my guide. Now I have to go to the shops to buy a copy, something I haven't done since 2007. (Yes, really - I've had free copies of the Telegraph delivered to my house for the past three years.)

Also, this is the second time in a fortnight that the newspaper deliverer has failed to deliver my newspaper on Sunday. If this happens again next week, I'm calling the subscriptions department to make a complaint.

Edit at 11:30: they better deliver the newspaper next week - there's a part two to the Easter Show guide, which is the Showbags and rides part.

During the Summer season, outdoor cinemas like to set up camp in the city. Two of those are the Moonlight Cinema and the St. George Open Air Cinema. The difference between the two is that St. George Open Air Cinema is more expensive as you actually get to sit on a chair (I think; I've never been to a session), whereas in Moonlight Cinema, you sit on the grass.

I'd always wanted to go to one of these outdoor cinema sessions for a few years. I remember trying to get Margaret to come with me to some movie once, but she wasn't interested. Last year was the year I finally got to go to a session - Moonlight Cinema (which for Sydney is held in Centennial Park each year) was holding a preview session of Fantastic Mr. Fox, two days before I was due to leave the country. A perfect way to spend time with friends before I went overseas and at the same time, show Emin (who was visiting us from Singapore) what you can do on Summer nights in Sydney. The only slight problem was that it fell on Margaret's birthday, so by inviting everyone to come along with me, I squashed any plans she had for the day. Luckily, she didn't mind, as long as I came to her birthday party the day after wearing a Santa hat.

The experience was quite cool, both figuratively and literally. Figuratively 'cause it was awesome sitting on a picnic blanket (thank goodness for Country Road tote bags!) with everyone, talking in the open air while waiting for the movie to start. Some people brought wine and food, making it more picnic-like, while others brought blankets (which proved to be handy later). You could rent these lounge things to sit on, if you wanted. Fiona picked a great spot to sit down (as you can see above; the tree branch frames the screen perfectly) at the back, with the toilets not too far away. We were on a slope, so we didn't have people's heads blocking our views. Literally, because it was FREEZING for a Summer night. And it sprinkled a little while we were watching the film. Margaret was my saviour for the night because she had a cardigan that she lent me, which I believe prevented me from getting sick the next day. (I love you, Margaret! Don't worry, I have my own lightweight cardigan now.)

The film? Brilliant. A few sceptics were among us 'cause they weren't impressed by the trailer, which we saw when we were watching Where The Wild Things Are, but they enjoyed it (I think; I know Margaret did 'cause she was gushing about it after the film). A bit fast paced for me - they seemed to shove the entire novel version in a really short space of time, and added a beginning and end in the space of ninety minutes. Nonetheless, I really liked it and hope to add it to my DVD collection one day. The trailer may not impress most people, but if you watch the film and STILL don't like it, I'll eat my cardigan.

I'd love to go to Moonlight Cinema again next Summer. It makes a nice change from watching a movie in an enclosed space. Yeah, the weather was a dampener (I love my puns), but it made a nice change from sitting in an enclosed room with a bunch of idiots who take photos of their feet in the middle of the movie such as when we went to watch Where The Wild Things Are.

P.S. There was a fight between some passengers who left the bus a few minutes after we got on. Made the more entertaining due to a on-board passenger calling 'Scuffle!' as they began fighting outside.

Yeah, my blog posts are a bit outdated. Lots to post about, including my trip to Malaysia and Singapore, my new mobile phone and random bits and pieces. At least it'll be a useful procrastination tool. *shifty*

Oh my God
I tried to keep count of how many times the phrase Oh my God or Oh my goodness was said on My Kitchen Rules tonight, because of this commerical I missed while watching Border Security yesterday, but read about on forums:

Before the first commerical break, I managed to count ELEVEN OMGs. Not as many as the show continued, then when I started talking to Stephanie on Messenger about it, I lost count, but there were at least three during our conversation, including two within five seconds of each other. I think there were about twenty instances of OMGs in the space of an hour.

My Kitchen Rules is such an entertaining show, especially when you watch it with a friend. Oh, and there's Pete and Manu, too . . . Channel 7 sure know how to pick attractive chefs for their cooking/reality TV shows - My Restaurant Rules and Curtis Stone, anyone? I don't think any hot chef could beat Manu, though - he has the French accent.

My previous experience in getting picture books delivered to my house was not positive. How can it be when dimwitted deliverymen shove your books into your mailbox, despite it being wrapped in cardboard and the fence holes not being wide enough to insert picture books flat? This time however, my most recent experience in getting them delivered is a happier one. I ordered two picture books from Play4Me for uni on Thursday the eleventh, and the following Tuesday, they got sent out (along with Anh's birthday present, which I had ordered the week before the eleventh). While Anh received her present on Thursday, I didn't get my picture books until Friday. But I didn't mind much, because they were delivered how they should be delivered - by the deliveryman walking up to your front door with your packages. It was the same person who delivered my CD from Juno. He gets kudos from me because he closed the gate properly, unlike most deliverymen - if you don't close the gate properly, the electric gate will smash into it when I use it later. Helped that the padded bags used to ship my books were too big for my mailbox. Love the way my books get packed by Play4Me and Chaos; wrapped in bubble wrap before being inserted into a bubble bag/padded bag. Their customer service is pretty good, too.

I hope my Book Depository order will be delivered in the same manner, when I get around to ordering it (why didn't I order it when it was under ninety bucks?!). You think they'll respond to my request if I ask them to put Do Not Bend on it? I don't trust Australia Post.

When I studied Children's Literature last year, one of the books we read was the first book in the Ranger's Apprentice series by John Flanagan. I really liked it, so towards the end of the year, sought out the rest of the series (there are nine books so far). The only problem? They had refreshed the first eight books with new covers to match the ninth book. As my copy of the first book was the old cover, and not being able to stand books that don't match, I hastily began my search of the old covers. (Luckily no one responded to my request for these books as my birthday present!) I could have just bought the new cover of the first book for $5 (which I think is an excellent way to encourage people to start a new series), but what would I do with two copies of The Ruins Of Gorlan? And I wouldn't have been able to score one of the best bargains of last year had I bought the new covers.

November 26 Armed with a Dymocks gift card in time for their Booklover Shopping Event (thanks Julie!), I deliberately planned my trip to the city with my friend Julie (not the Julie who gave me the gift card; that'd be my cousin) so that it'd be on the same day, where I could go to five Dymocks stores (if necessary) to get the books I wanted. My plan of attack was to start outside the city with the Broadway store, before making our way up George St into the city. Luckily, the books I wanted were found in the first two stores I went to, but I ended up going to three 'cause I wanted to check out the range in the main city store. The two books I wanted were The Burning Bridge - the second book in the Ranger's Apprentice series and Twitterature.

Dymocks Broadway This went off to a brilliant start. Couldn't get in the damn store, for one. Julie and I used the escalator entrance, only to find that the gate was locked! Apparently the staff knew had no idea where the key to the gate was, according to the girl who was already stuck at the top of the escalator. To make things worse, there was no way we could get down, because there was only one escalator, and that went up. In the end, we all ended up going back down by pressing the stop button on the escalator and walking around to the main entrance, which was on another level. Memo to Dymocks Broadway: leave a note next time, yeah?

Result: They had Twitterature, and book five of the Ranger's Apprentice series with the old cover. Really wanted The Burning Bridge, and I was sure Twitterature could be found everywhere, so didn't end up buying anything. They also have a lot of Studio Ghibli DVDs. Store was pretty quiet.

Dymocks World Square Had no problems getting in; there was only one entrance. Very quiet, as with the Broadway store. Kudos to their staff for knowing that the latest book in the Ranger's Apprentice series just got released. No kudos towards the lady who served me who forgot to knock $5.50 from my Booklover card, despite my asking her to. Luckily I wanted to buy something else.

Result: They had the edition of The Burning Bridge that I wanted! They had Twitterature as well.

Dymocks 424 George St (aka the main city store) This was PACKED. A sign advertising their 20% off sale (unlike the other two, which kept it a secret, prompting me to ask the staff in World Square whether they were participating), celebrity signings, free food . . . I've always held a soft spot for the main city store as I've gotten lucky twice when buying something there - the first time was when they had a three for two sale, and instead of giving me the cheapest book for free ($8), they gave me the most expensive book instead ($20), and when I asked about it, told me to keep it quiet. (I think it was 'cause that was scanned last rather than first. $36 worth of books for $16!) The other time was when I had to return $50 worth of books so I could use my $6.something on my Booklover card (the lady didn't ask if I wanted to use it and I assumed that all staff did it automatically for you). Instead of earning $43 worth of Booklover points, I earned $92 worth of points. SCORE! They usually have the books I want, too.

Result: But not today. They had the entire series, alright - with the new covers. Don't you hate it when publishing companies decide to switch covers halfway through a series? (According to the official Facebook page, they ran out of photos.) Ended up buying Twitterature here; cost me $2.02 after applying the 20% discount, the $6.something left on my gift card and the $5.50 from my Booklover card.

Mission accomplished!

December Now that I had the first two books, it was time to concentrate on getting the rest of the series. In point form, here's what happened:

  • At the end of November, I tried to order The Icebound Land (the third book) from Big W Entertainment, since I had a $5 gift voucher, they were the cheapest and were offering free shipping. Unfortunately, they couldn't fulfil my order and gave my money and gift voucher back.
  • Ten days later, I discovered what might be my bargain of the year (apart from my cheap Moleskines from The Book Depository) - books five to eight, with old covers, in a box, on clearance from Target, FOR FOURTEEN DOLLARS AND EIGHTY-NINE CENTS! Each book retails for $16.95! I could NOT pass the opportunity to snap it up! I didn't want the box, so I discarded it by sticking it in the recycling bin. Now, they're being sold for $10 a box. Excellent, excellent bargain.
  • A few days later, having suddenly found myself in the possession of two more Dymocks gift cards (one courtesy of Emin; thanks!), I purchased the fourth book, Oakleaf Bearers from Dymocks Liverpool, effectively making it for free. I got the lady who served me to check whether it was possible to order in The Icebound Land, and it was, but unfortunately, I wouldn't be in the country much longer.
  • So with that in mind, I asked my cousin Jenny if she could buy it for me when Dymocks had their 20% off sale after Christmas while I was overseas. Had I known that Borders in Queensbay Mall, Penang had The Icebound Land, I wouldn't have asked her to buy it. *laughs* So when I saw it, I sent a text message to her asking whether she had bought it. She had; a Dymocks guy somehow managed to find a copy somewhere. A bit bent, but I didn't care, so long as I didn't pay RRP for it. That's all eight books done and dusted! Unfortunately, until I got back home, I couldn't start reading the third book, and thus, the rest of the series . . . Typical that the next book I wanted to read turned out to be the most difficult book to source.

February I went and used a Target gift card I had on the ninth (and latest) book , Halt's Peril. I still have $8.10 left on my Dymocks card from Emin; might use that on the tenth book should it be out come this year's Christmas shopping event. Either that, or a Popular Penguin from the third collection to be published in July.

Tl; dr: I got my old-cover Ranger's Apprentice books - all eight of them. Four for less than the price of one, two with gift cards and one courtesy of my cousin who bought it for me when I was overseas. Score! Oh, and I bought the latest one with the new cover as well.

Seriously, I think Wi-Fi is one of the greatest inventions ever. You don't need a laptop to use it. You can use a mobile phone, a portable media player, anything that has Wi-Fi capabilities. Unlike a wired Internet connection where you must stay put, you can walk around and still be able to use the Internet, so long as you're in the network area.

Last year, I complained that the free McDonald's Wi-Fi service at Westfield Penrith Plaza was crappy. It could be that store only, for I find that the services of the Centro Roselands store and the Westfield Parramatta Level 3 and Level 5 stores worked brilliantly on my Nokia E63. I didn't drop out at all! And I didn't need to stand near the counter, either. The McDonald's window I used to log on kept popping up, which was annoying, but that was rectified by closing said window, which didn't interrupt my connection. Could even use eBuddy and send a few instant messages to my friends.

What I want to talk about in particular is the Level 3 store. Their Wi-Fi is so goddamn awesome that you can use it an entire level up - in the children's section of Borders Parramatta (which is on Level 4)! Score one for availability! That means that I could compare Borders' store prices to Borders' online prices via Booko, if I wanted. I can check my e-mail in the (relatively) quiet children's section, where it's air-conditioned, while browsing children's books. If that isn't made of win, then I don't know what does. Maybe if it worked in the magazines section, but unlike the children's section, that isn't right above McDonald's Level 3 . . .

As I didn't get my newspapers this weekend, I checked online to view the status of the subscription I had supposedly taken out. It said it expired. Looks like they finally cottoned on to the fact that I was scoring free weekend newspapers from them for the past two months. (WHY DID YOU CONTINUE DELIVERING MY PAPER WHILE I WAS ON HOLIDAYS?!) Debit MasterCard still hasn't been charged, and I don't think it'll ever be. I hope.

Will probably take up a new subscription in the form of this year's Uni Card, which includes seven-day delivery over the Summer holidays.

Back in October or November, the right hinge of my ASUS laptop broke away from the keyboard section, and a few hours later, the left hinge also broke. I would have gotten it fixed back then, but I had assignments to complete. When my assignments were completed, I decided to wait until after I came back from holidays just in case of the Christmas season, where my laptop might be fixed in January, but not being home to get it back. I continued using the laptop by leaning the screen against the windowsill and plugging an external keyboard in as the laptop keyboard was too far to reach.

A week after I came back from overseas, I decided that it was time to get my laptop fixed, especially since my warranty expires on the 10th this month. Luckily, ASUS agreed via e-mail to fix it under warranty (you might not be able to get through on the telephone but their eSupport service is there as a back-up; responds in an hour or so; excellent) and on Tuesday, picked up my laptop, which I managed to close up to put in a box, and took it away to BP Computers. They said that the person picking it would come in the morning, but he arrived at 1:30; I had fallen asleep by the time he arrived.

Spent the next few days surfing the Internet using a combination of my old laptop, which lags badly at times, but is still usable despite its age (five years old) and the monitor not working (plugged in an external monitor), and the Wi-Fi function on my new Nokia E63, which is how I once drained the entire battery in a day.

This morning around eight o'clock, the doorbell rang. It was a courier - with my laptop. How fast! ASUS's service is bloody fantastic! Definitely will influence me to select an ASUS laptop again should I need a new one; their laptops have a 24-month warranty. If only their batteries had a 24-month warranty as well . . .

From the most wanted tours of 2010 on Inthemix:

Don't get your hopes up, Wendy. *sigh*

Thanks for getting the regular newspaper deliverer back. Unlike last year when my paper didn't show up on Saturday half the time, my paper has consistently showed up on my front lawn nice and early on Saturday morning, week after week after week. Too consistently, you might say.

Although my subscription expired on November 30, for the past three weeks, I have continued to receive my weekend papers on my front lawn, much to my surprise. Unfortunately, this will mean an awkward phone call to your department when I ask you to I have just discovered that I can suspend my delivery online! No awkward phone calls! But what is this?

Subscription Term: Every 4 weeks - Direct Debit until you advise us to stop
I certainly don't recall taking out a weekend subscription to your paper that'll be charged every four weeks! Is this why I keep receiving the paper? Are you going to charge my Debit MasterCard? (That's the last time I buy my Uni Card online if you do.) Or has some generous person quietly gifted me a weekend subscription for my birthday? I doubt my luck extends that far.

But alas! I will end up having to call you. I cannot suspend my subscription online because you require more information.

We require more notice of your suspension to process it online. Please alter your commencement date and resubmit or phone 13 66 66 to have your urgent request processed.
Guess I shouldn't have left it so late. But on the other hand, I can try and get more information on this supposed weekend subscription . . .

So I called you. No human conversation, just a lady telling me what buttons to press on my handset. I have left it too late to suspend my home delivery on the date I desired. Apparently it should be done a week before you want to suspend it and not two days before, but this is the first time I have ever needed to suspend a delivery, so please excuse my ignorance.

We shall see what happens after January 30. If I find that there's a $14 charge on my Debit MasterCard, I'll be cancelling my subscription immediately. And resuming it again when I buy next year's Uni Card . . .

Edit on 29/1/10 at 21:57: Jesus, they kept delivering the paper while I was overseas, despite my account saying I was on vacation! Although it was handy getting Sunday's paper on Monday, especially after getting jealous over the fact that someone had managed to score a copy of a Sunday Telegraph on the plane from Singapore to Sydney. And no, my Debit MasterCard hasn't been charged yet.

Last time I was at Sydney Airport, I was arriving home from Malaysia. That was well over five years ago.

Over the next week, I'll be hitting the airport twice in a week - today to pick up Emin, who's visiting from Singapore for a month, then again on Monday to catch a flight to Singapore (ironic, isn't it - Emin's visiting Australia while I won't be here, and vice versa) before heading to Malaysia a few days later.

I hope we don't get lost . . . and that we can find Emin in the airport . . .

If you read the post on the CDs I bought this year (which you probably didn't, especially if you know the kind of music I like listening to), you'll have noticed that I was waiting for Kelpe's Cambio Wechsel to arrive, after ordering it earlier in the day. Since my preferred entertainment supplier wanted to charge $33 for it and I couldn't even be sure if they could source me a copy (it was 'discontinued' a few times while on my wishlist) and Juno Records over in the UK were selling it for $16 (shipping and a PayPal fee made it under $21), I bought it from Juno instead.

I was expecting my CD to arrive in a bubble bag, slotted into my mailbox. Instead, a deliveryman (the same one who attempted to give me next door's parcel the day before, despite my house number appearing on my mailbox) personally delivered my CD to the door, because the package looked like this:

WHY SO BIG?! The size of the CD was two centimetres shorter than the size of the shipping label - surely it didn't need that much cardboard! Kudos to Juno though for shipping it out so quickly! I'd definitely use them again for stuff that I can't get/is too expensive in Australia. Thank goodness the UK exchange rate is very favourable. *grins*

Skipping the country in ten days. I think everyone except me has finished packing. I don't know what quantities to pack, though. I know what reading material I want to bring along, but not the number of T-shirts . . .

Unlike books, it's quite easy to stick to a CD quota, which for me is one per month. While books can cost as little as $10 (yay for Popular Penguins!), CDs - the ones I tend to buy anyway - cost at least $20.

Here are some statistics on the twelve CDs I bought:

  • All except two were either released in 2008 or 2009
  • The two that weren't were from Boards Of Canada; both of them came from Discogs
  • All but three features some sort of electronic music
  • Seven of them arrived by post*; the other five were bought from a storefront
  • Three of them arrived by post from Europe*
  • The most expensive CD was from Röyksopp
  • The least expensive CD was from Seekae
The list
  • OceanLab - Sirens Of The Sea (2008)
  • The Whitest Boy Alive - Rules (2009)
  • Seekae - The Sound Of Trees Falling On People (2008)
  • Röyksopp - Junior (Limited Edition) (2009)
  • Lady Of The Sunshine - Smoking Gun (2009)
  • Mountains In The Sky - Electron Suite (2008)
  • Goldfrapp - Seventh Tree (Deluxe Edition) (2008)
  • Boards Of Canada - The Campfire Headphase (2005)
  • Boards Of Canada - Geogaddi (Limited Edition) (2002)
  • Air - Love 2 (2009)
  • Kings Of Convenience - Declaration Of Dependence (2009)
  • Kelpe - Cambio Wechsel (2009)
* The last one (Kelpe) has yet to arrive; I bought it this morning.

Next year, there's new albums from Pivot (I think), Efterklang, Angus and Julia Stone and Röyksopp, who were supposed to release Senior this year and appear on the Playground Weekender lineup for next year. *sigh*

I was supposed to be born today, but I refused to come out of my mummy's tummy, so they cut me out of her. I'm serious.

So if anyone got/is planning to get me Dymocks gift cards, can I please have them before the 26th? Pretty please? I'm on a book ban (which doesn't apply when I'm buying books paid for with gift cards) . . .

• My short-term memory is notoriously poor in comparison to my long-term memory, which is quite excellent, if I do say so myself.

It said to wait for the Christmas sales - do they mean the sales before Christmas, or after Christmas? If the latter, then I won't be here! *wails*

I haven't done this in a while, but I love this song too much to not feature it in my blog somehow. Riot On An Empty Street by Kings Of Convenience. My favourite song from Declaration Of Dependence, no contest. It's quiet and delicate-sounding, yet it sounds powerful. I love the lyrics, too (where the first half of the title of this post comes from):

Why, why so quiet?
Oh, my mysterious
country singer she asks.
My life, it's a riot.
I'm climbing barricades
in empty streets at night.

When I'm done
fighting shadows,
25 postcards
in a box in my room.
Telephone conversations,
gas slowly leaking out of
a heart-shaped balloon.

It's a dangerous game
that I'm not sure if I
could keep playing for long.
It's a dangerous game,
it's a very fine line
and if one step is wrong,
I'll have no cards to play,
and that's why
I've got nothing to say
tonight.
I've got nothing to say
tonight.

Edit on 11/11/09 at 10:43: I LOVE YOU ANH! She bought me Where The Wild Things Are for my birthday - the original storybook and the movie storybook! I now have the poster stuck on my bedroom wall, where I can look at it while at my desk. *happy face*

Yesterday I went to Campsie with my family and came home with the above edibles for my personal consumption:

  • Nong Shim Curry Ramen, which I expected to be made in Korea, as Nong Shim is a Korean brand. Alas, I discovered that it was made in China.
  • Sangaria Orange Soda Drink - my brother and I bought a bottle each, 'cause I'm sick with a cold at the moment. Tasted like orange Fanta, but more acidic and fizzy. The bottle is cool; why can't soft drink come in aluminium bottles here?
  • Paldo (seems to have changed its logo since the last time I came across it) Hot & Spicy Hwa Ramyun. Hopefully this, along with the curry ramen, will be spicy enough! The best hot and spicy noodles are the ones which require you to reach for tissues so you can blow your nose to get rid of the snot.
Yay for instant noodles! Such a shame they're bad for you and you can only eat it once a week (which is something my old Computer Studies teacher Mr Macpherson would agree with; he doesn't like instant noodles).

I can't really call my post Fantastic Foreign Food if I haven't eaten all of it yet, can I? But I wanted to use alliteration . . .

Edit at 14:08: Had the Nong Shim Curry Ramen for lunch. WHERE IS THE SPICE?! Just as disappointing as the Fantastic Chicken Curry noodles-in-a-cup my high school sold. I was sick when I ate those though, and I'm sick now, so maybe my tastebuds were out of whack . . .

Really, if they didn't know how to spell refrigerator, then they should have just put fridge instead. At least three-year-old children can pronounce fridge easily. Such a shame; I like the fact that the packaging and materials are at least 95 percent recycled. (It was the packaging that prompted me to pick up the toy.)

The culprit? Good ol' Kmart. Perhaps I should suggest to Kmart via their feedback form that they need to hire a proofreader or two.

You want to watch a film from the Nordic Film Festival, but you can't find anyone to go with you. What do you do?

You go watch the film by yourself. Not a bad experience, actually. Helped that I was watching it in a great cinema.

Last Friday, I went to the city so I could watch Terribly Happy (Frygtelig Lykkelig in Danish) at the Dendy Opera Quays. It's described as a 'black comedy' . . . was hooked by the film's description and the 'comedy' part, but must have ignored the 'black'; it definitely wasn't laugh-out-loud comedy. That's not to say it was a bad film, however; quite the opposite. I found myself trying to predict what was going to happen next and was off the mark each time. The lead actor was quite easy on the eye, too. The lead actress reminded me of Kirsten Dunst; I think they look similar. I wouldn't mind getting Frytelig Lykkelig on DVD one day (I doubt it'll ever be released in Australia, though).

Can I saw how freaking awesome the Dendy chain of cinemas are? Here's why:

  • minimal ads - ten minutes of ads and that's it. No repeating/same kind of ads, too. As an aside, The Nordic Film Festival had ads from its sponsors; watched this very nice one of Finnish landscape only to be disappointed by the fact that it was for a vodka. What I found hilarious was that the song the Nordic Film Festival used to promote their films was the Afterlife Remix of Jakatta's American Dream. Couldn't they have used some music produced by Nordic musicians like Röyksopp's Eple?
  • clean, unlike a certain cinema chain starting with H
  • no reserved seating, unlike another cinema chain starting with E or G, depending on where you live
  • no idiots
  • cheaper than the major chain cinemas, and shows better films
  • cheaper candy bar prices, too - I went to watch Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince at Hoyts on a Tuesday and my food cost more than my ticket.
The Dendy Opera Quays one in particular gets mega kudos because
  • there's no reception in the cinema, meaning that people can't text in the middle of a film and irritate everyone with their mobile's light (for Vodafone, anyway; wanted to go on mobile Internet before the film started only to discover that I couldn't)
  • they have curtains that pull away to reveal the screen - every cinema should have these!
  • they played good music, including Air's Playground Love (which reminded me that I have still yet to watch The Virgin Suicides and listen to the score Air did for the film)
  • the location of the cinemas meant that you could kill time before the movie started by taking photos of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge and walking in the Botanic Gardens.
Dendy for the win!

Finished reading this for uni recently. Unlike the previous book I read for uni (D.H. Lawrence's Women In Love), it was good. Shorter, not full of random nonsense as much as Women In Love (which is so bad; it's worse than the Twilight saga), but still a bit difficult to read (requiring use of the Internet to help me keep track of the characters).

I like the fact that Dying is blurry in the photo.

The condiment you spread on your food known as strawberry jam

A just-opened jar of IXL strawberry jam. Goes well with crumpet toast - yum!

The Jelly Belly bean flavour Strawberry Jam

Finally had the opportunity to try this flavour when I saw that Sugar Fix in Miranda had more than the standard flavours usually seen in David Jones and Darrell Lea. Nice, but needs more sugar. Until I try the Strawberry Daiquiri one, the Strawberry Cheesecake one will be my preferred strawberry Jelly Belly flavour.

The Swatch watch Strawberry Jam

Bought this watch two years ago since I needed a spare Swatch watch. I wear this one more than my Bludablu one as it has numbers and a second hand and goes well with my clothes more. Unlike my Bludablu one, I didn't have to punch any holes in this one so I could wear it - hurrah! It's a gorgeous colour, too (my photo appears to have made it lighter in colour than it actually is).

The album called Strawberry Jam The Wikipedia article on the Animal Collective album Strawberry Jam.

On Friday, my brother got his Learner Driver Licence. His licence expires in five years. When I had my Learner Driver Licence five years ago, it had an expiry date of three years. Unlike my brother, who has to do 120 hours in order to be eligible for a P1 Driver Licence, I only had to do 50 hours, which I guess is why his licence has a longer expiry date.

Anyway, because I am an excellent procrastinator, I'd thought I'd drag out my old licences (I'm currently on my fourth - my unrestricted licence, which means I can legally teach my brother how to drive) and see when they expired:

  • Learner: 21 December 2007 (three years' validity)
  • P1: 26 October 2007 (eighteen months' validity)
  • P2: 27 October 2009 (thirty months' validity)
  • Unrestricted #1: 24 July 2012 (three years' validity)
And just to waste even more time, here's how much each one cost at the time, compared to now:
  • Learner: $16 in December 2004, $21 in October 2009
  • P1: $40 in April 2006, $47 in October 2009
  • P2: $68 in April 2007, $75 in October 2009
  • Unrestricted #1: $113 for three years in July 2009, still the same price as of October 2009
OK. I've gotten that out of my system. Time to be more productive.

All acquired within the past week. Bought Geogaddi at the end of last month, however; only just arrived in the post today. Damn you, Australia Post!

Geogaddi The title of this post comes from the second track of this album, which I'm listening to at the moment in the dark to create a scary atmosphere, which works quite well when the only source of light is the graphic equaliser of the stereo dancing to Music Is Math. More crunchy-sounding music compared to their other albums. Out of all the songs I've listened to so far, there's only one I don't like much (Gyroscope) Gyroscope sounds much better when listened to through earphones. It needs another listen (preferably with earphones, in the dark), but it's quite good.

Declaration Of Dependence I can't believe this cost me $26! For crying out loud, my limited-edition copy of Geogaddi from Discogs was less than $25 delivered to my house - FROM ENGLAND. Geez JB Hi-Fi, what happened to the hot price of $19.99 as per your website? Even the independent record store Red Eye has it cheaper at $22. Plus it was made in Australia, and not Europe! I must give the Penrith store kudos for actually HAVING the album in the first place, though. Very nice album to listen to when it's not raining heavily. I still can't figure out who does the solo in Riot On An Empty Street (which is my favourite song from the album), despite having heard it at least fifty times by now. After reading the album booklet (something you can't do with the iTunes download equivalent, for there is no digital booklet), I shall conclude that it is Eirik rather than Erlend.

Love 2 I can't believe that when I went to buy this on Friday at JB Hi-Fi Liverpool, they didn't have it in stock! They didn't have Declaration Of Dependence either, but I was expecting that (Penrith always seems to have a better range than Liverpool), so it wasn't as shocking to me. Luckily when I went back the next day, they had it, so I was as happy as a clam again. Definitely not worthy of a four out of ten rating as handed by Pitchfork. I know not everyone will like it (although the majority do), but it's worthy of a passing grade! Apparently Air are coming back in April next year (quite quick for a return; it took them ten years to play live in Australia), so I hope I can go and see them again (with a paid ticket this time, Mum and Dad) and see songs like So Light Is Her Footfall and Eat My Beat played live!

So now I have one CD left as part of my one-CD-a-month quota . . . is Röyksopp's Senior coming out this year? Because if not, I might as well go and blow it on something from my Discogs shopping cart while the exchange rate is looking fantastic (56 pence compared to 39 pence this time last year) or Kelpe's new album Cambio Wechsel or something . . .

Taken while waiting at the intersection of the Great Western Highway and Carlisle Avenue, Minchinbury. Not ideal weather for listening to Kings Of Convenience's Declaration Of Dependence; couldn't hear it properly while the rain was pelting my car as I drove home from uni yesterday afternoon and ended up stopping the CD player a few times because the heavy rain was too loud for delicate-sounding music.

And while I struggled to drive home in the rain, I missed out on the hailstorm at home. How depressing!

I think this might be my music video of the year . . . It's directed by Martin de Thurah (who did the awesome music video for Röyksopp's What Else Is There?). Two reasons why I love this music video:

  • it has subtitles to translate the spoken Danish in the beginning; I love my subtitles!
  • it has men in suits and damn, do they look good in them! I have a thing for men in suits just as I have a thing for girls in pigtails.
I can't remember how I discovered Mew (I think it was from iTunes' weekly newsletter), but I do know why I checked them out:
  • they're from Denmark (home of Efterklang and Trentemøller, two other Danish musical acts I love)
  • the title of their new album is ridiculously long (but not as long as this Soulwax compilation) - No More Stories Are Told Today I'm Sorry They Washed Away No More Stories The World Is Grey I'm Tired Let's Wash Away
  • the Wikipedia article for said album described the album's genre as the following: alternative rock, indie rock, dream pop, progressive rock, post-rock
  • said album was well received by critics
All those points paid off. Finished listening to No More Stories last week; brilliant! Quite interested in checking out their other albums now, starting with their previous album, And The Glass Handed Kites . . .

Edit on 5/10/09 at 20:52: I've watched the music video too many times now and I swear Bo (the one with the moustache and awesome bow tie) reminds me of Professor Lupin from the Harry Potter films. They look similar to each other and they're both being tortured . . . Only difference is that one is a musician and the other is a werewolf.

A few items of clothing I own has this instruction on it: dry flat in shade.

I don't understand what it means. It doesn't say hang up in shade, but dry flat in shade. Is this what they want me to do?

Bah, why are washing instructions so complex sometimes? HELP!
